hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the input matrix. It is a 2D list (or array) with dimensions m x n. Make sure you can access elements using their row and column indices.
Identify the elements that need to be replaced. Specifically, you will be looking for elements that are equal to -1. Consider how you can traverse the matrix to find these elements.
For each -1 found in the matrix, you will need to determine the maximum value in its respective column. Think about how you can iterate through each column to find the maximum value.
Remember that you need to keep the original matrix intact while creating a new matrix for the answer. You can initialize the answer matrix as a copy of the original matrix.
As you iterate through the matrix, you can use a nested loop: the outer loop for rows and the inner loop for columns. This will help you access each element in the matrix.
When you find a -1, you can use another loop to find the maximum value in that particular column. Keep track of the maximum value as you iterate through the rows of that column.
Consider edge cases, such as when a column contains only -1 values. However, the problem guarantees at least one non-negative integer per column, so you won't have to handle columns with all -1s.
Make sure to update the answer matrix only at the positions where you found -1. Use the maximum value you found in the column to replace the -1.
After processing all elements, ensure that your answer matrix is returned in the correct format. It should be a 2D list with the same dimensions as the input matrix.
Finally, think about the overall time complexity of your approach. You will likely have a nested loop structure, so consider how this affects performance, especially with the maximum constraints.

questionNotes: The input matrix is guaranteed to have dimensions 2 <= m, n <= 50.
Each column contains at least one non-negative integer, so you won't encounter columns with all -1s.
The output should be a new matrix with the same dimensions as the input, where -1 values are replaced by the maximum value of their respective columns.
